newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: RUGBY UNION-LIONS MAKE ONE DAY DIVERSION TO BLOEMFONTEIN.
newsitem.headline: RUGBY UNION-LIONS MAKE ONE DAY DIVERSION TO BLOEMFONTEIN.

text.p: A diminished British Lions squad of 21 will fly in and out of Bloemfontein on the day for Tuesday's game against Free State.
The remainder of the party will fly directly to Durban to begin preparations for what could be the decisive second test after the Lions' 25-16 victory over the Springboks at Newlands on Saturday.
The day trip has become an increasingly popular trend in South Africa with the All Blacks having set the pattern on their victorious tour last year.
"It's one of the facts of modern professional rugby life," said manager Fran Cotton.
"With the tests on three successive Saturdays you can't afford to spend time in these places."
The Lions will name their team for the match against Free State on Monday but it is bound to include a handful of players who were involved in the test victory.

Tony Underwood, Simon Shaw and Eric Miller -- none of whom were involved on Saturday -- have all had influenza while test prop Tom Smith and flyhalf Gregor Townsend are recovering from slight injuries. That means the selectors may have only 30 names to choose from.
But with eight victories from their nine matches on tour, confidence is running high for the Lions' final match against Super 12 opposition.
"Free State are arguably the best team in South Africa at the moment," said Cotton.
"They are a very tough provincial team and it will be a hell of a game. We are hoping that most of the test side won't be playing.
"When all is said and done you are remembered for your test results."
